subtitle: Despite appearances, this recipe is actually fairly simple, and the end result is definitely worth the effort. Great for picnics and buffet lunches.

method.text: Preheat oven to 200°C. Lightly grease a 20 cm round spring-clip cake tin.

Mince half the pork with the onion and apple in a food processor. Transfer to a bowl. Mix in the garlic, seasoning and herbs. Finely chop the remaining pork with the bacon. Stir into the minced mixture.

Sift the flour and salt into a bowl; make a well in the centre. Place the lard, milk and water in a pan. Heat until the fat dissolves, then bring to the boil. Pour the liquid into the well. Stir in quickly to make a soft dough.

On a lightly floured surface, knead the dough lightly until smooth. Put a quarter of the dough in a bowl, covered with a cloth. Roll out the remaining dough. Use to line the cake tin, smoothing evenly into base and sides.
Spoon half the pork mixture into the pastry case with the hard-boiled eggs on top. Spoon over the remaining pork mixture, making sure it is evenly packed.

Roll out the remaining pastry to a round, large enough to top the pie. Dampen the pastry edges with a little water then press the edges together to seal. Trim off any excess pastry to decorate, using a little cold water to attach, and crimp the edges of the pie.

Place the pie on a baking tray. Brush the top with beaten egg. Make a hole in the centre of the lid for steam to escape. Insert a small rolled up piece of greaseproof paper into the hole, to act as a chimney.
Cook in oven for 30 min. Reduce temperature to 160°C and cook for a 1hr 15 min, cover the top with foil if it browns too much.
Remove from oven. Leave to cool completely. Dissolve the gelatine in the stock. Insert a funnel into the roll of paper and, very slowly, pour as much of the stock as possible into the pie.
Leave to chill for several hours or overnight. Turn out and serve in slices.

title: Raised pork pie
